See a Rare, Bus-Sized Giant Phantom Jelly Wade Through Ocean Waters Off the Coast of Argentina
A recent deep-sea expedition along the countryâ€™s entire length documented the jellyfish, along with a surprising number of other species
During an expedition off the coast of Argentina, scientists saw something unexpected. In December, they spied a rare jellyfish roughly the length of a school bus, known as the giant phantom jelly, wading through Atlantic waters at about 820 feet below the surface.
â€œThere was a mixture of excitement and disbelief,â€ says MarÃ­a Emilia Bravo, a marine biologist at the University of Buenos Aires in Argentina and the expeditionâ€™s chief scientist, to Alexa Robles-Gil at the New York Times. â€œIts ethereal and delicate presence in such an extreme environment was deeply surprising.â€
The researchers stumbled upon the massive jellyfish while using a remotely operated vehicle (ROV) called SuBastian on an expedition spanning Argentinaâ€™s entire coast. Unlike some jellyfish, giant phantom jellies lack stinging tentacles. Instead, they use ribbon-like arms to grab prey, typically plankton or small fish, and pull them into their mouths.
The gargantuan creatures can reach lengths of 33 feet and have bells more than 3 feet wide. But despite their massive size, the elusive creatures have been spotted only about 120 times since the first specimen was collected in 1899. Thatâ€™s because they prefer to lurk in the â€œmidnight zone,â€ a part of the ocean ranging from 3,300 to 13,100 feet deep, that is shrouded in complete darkness.
Thanks to ROVs, scientists are finally getting a good look at the animals. â€œUp until recently, nobody was able to actually see it in its natural habitat and in its full glory,â€ says Steve Haddock, a marine biologist at the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute who was not involved in the expedition, to the Times. Scientists at the institute have previously spotted the rare jellies off the California coast.
The main goal of the Argentinian voyage, operated by the Schmidt Ocean Institute, was to locate cold seeps. These are areas of the ocean floor where chemicals such as methane and hydrogen sulfide escape from cracks and serve as energy for microbes, forming the foundation of the marine food web. While operating the ROV from a ship, the researchers found one active seep measuring just under half a square mile, per a statement.
The team also uncovered a surprising amount of biodiversity. They discovered the largest known Bathelia candida coral reef, which, at 0.15 square miles, is almost the size of Vatican City. It was located about 370 miles farther south than its known range.
Additionally, the researchers spotted a whale carcass on the seafloor about 12,800 feet below the surface, marking Argentinaâ€™s first deep-water whale fall. These remains can create complex temporary ecosystems that provide food and shelter for deep-sea animals and other organisms.
Did you know? How whale falls help other creatures
Different marine communities benefit from the various stages of a whale carcassâ€™ degradation. Scavenger species quickly pick off soft tissue in just a few months. Organic debris adds to the sediments for a year or more. And the skeleton can provide structures and nutrients for invertebrates for years to decades.
Whatâ€™s more, the team documented 28 potential new species, including worms, sea urchins, corals, sea snails and sea anemones.
â€œWe were not expecting to see this level of biodiversity in the Argentine deep sea and are so excited to see it teeming with life,â€ Bravo says in the statement. â€œSeeing all the biodiversity, ecosystem functions and connectivity unfolding together was incredible. We opened a window into our countryâ€™s biodiversity only to find there are so many more windows left to be opened.â€

What Is a Stoat? Learn Five Fun Facts About the Adorable Weasels Chosen as the Olympic Mascots
Milo and Tina, a pair of sibling stoats, are representing this yearâ€™s winter games in Italy
Olympic mascots date back to the 1968 Winter Olympics in Grenoble, France. Shuss, an abstract man on skis, was designed in just one night and showcased unofficially as the â€œcharacterâ€ to represent the games.
Since then, almost every subsequent Olympics has revealed a mascot, ranging from historically significant to strange and cute. Barcelona selected a humanoid Pyrenean mountain dog drawn in a cubist style in 1992, Atlanta picked the indescribable Izzyâ€”â€œnot an animal, nor a human figure, nor an objectâ€â€”in 1996, and Beijing in 2022 chose a lively panda.
Fun fact: The Olympic mascot was once a hat
The 2024 Paris Olympic Gamesâ€™ mascot, a funny-looking hat with legs known as a phryge, evoked the revolutionary ideals of France.
This time around, two mascots will represent the action at 2026 Winter Olympics: a pair of sibling stoats named Milo and Tina. Being teenagers, they are also described by the Olympic Committee as the â€œfirst openly Gen-Z mascotsâ€ to be featured at the games.
Tina, who represents the Olympic Games, is named after Cortina dâ€™Ampezzo, one of the Italian host cities, while her younger brother Milo, representing the Paralympic Games, is named after Milan, the other host city. Their love of sports and of being outdoors is a symbol of the â€œcontemporary, vibrant and dynamic Italian spirit.â€
The pair are joined by snowdrop blossoms called The Flo, which, according to their bio, are â€œsix curious and irresistible little flowersâ€ and a â€œsymbol of rebirth.â€
The furry little mascots and their snowy companions were chosen with input from primary and secondary schools in Italy, with the Italian Ministry of Education receiving more than 1,600 designs from students before releasing a poll for residents to choose between two mascots, a pair of flowers and the stoats, with the public ultimately deciding on the stoats.
So what are these small, slender animals? Here are five fun facts about stoats in honor of their recognition as the Olympic mascot.
1. Stoats are small mustelids, closely related to otters and ferrets.
Stoats, or Mustela erminea, are a species of mustelid native to Eurasia and the northern parts of North America. This puts them in the weasel family, along with ferrets, otters, badgers and wolverines. Stoats are also known by many namesâ€”sometimes, theyâ€™re called ermines or short-tailed weasels.
They have long, slender bodies that range from about 35 to 45 centimeters (about 14 to 18 inches), including the tail, and an average lifespan of two to five years. The mammals are small but powerful predators, hunting mostly rabbits and rodents. Though they are smaller than most adult rabbits, stoats are easily able to kill this prey due to their skilled hunting techniques and excellent hearing and vision.
Stoats generally mate in the spring or summer, but they delay the implantation of fertilized eggs until the next spring, in order to wait for a more abundant food supply.
2. Some stoats turn white in winter to camouflage with the snow.
Some stoats that reside in colder climates possess an extraordinary ability to change their coat from the typical brown to a bright white in the winter, and these animals are often called ermines when they have the light coloration. This feature allows them to blend in with and become almost invisible to both predators and prey. When it comes to the Olympic mascots, Tina sports the ermine winter coat, and Milo has the brown summer coat.
However, with the climate getting warmer and snow cover melting at faster speeds, the ermineâ€™s remarkable ability to turn white may hinder its chances of survival.
â€œThe ermine faces a mismatch when it finds itself completely white in a world that should be white, but is no longer so,â€ Marco Granata, a biologist at the University of Turin in Italy, who has been studying ermines in the countryâ€™s Alps, tells Alexandria Sage of the Agence France-Presse.
3. Stoats may perform a â€œdance of deathâ€ to confuse rabbits.
If a stoat struggles to chase down a rabbit, it has another trick up its sleeve: The animal might bust a move. By repeatedly rolling, jumping and twisting in midair, the stoat â€œdancesâ€ and momentarily stuns the rabbit, allowing the predator to take advantage of its confusion and deliver a fatal blow. Some scientists, however, have suggested the odd behavior is linked to parasitic infections rather than being a deliberate hunting attempt.
4. Stoats are extremely skilled swimmers and excellent climbers.
Stoats are natural swimmers with the ability to paddle for prolonged periods of time. A 2013 study published in Biological Invasions found that stoats are capable of swimming greater distances than animal researchers had previously thought.
The carnivoresâ€™ agility makes them exceptional climbers as well, hunting both day and night. These traits make stoats formidable predators, especially in areas like New Zealand, where they were introduced by humans and became an invasive species.
5. Stoats have a jet-black tip on their tail.
One way to tell whether an animal is a stoat is to look at its tail. Stoats sport tails that are about half the length of the rest of their body and end in a black tip. Even those stoats that turn white in the winter retain their black tip, which is thought to help them avoid predators by distracting birds of prey.

See the Beauty of Corals, Beehives, Mushrooms and More in These 11 Images From the Close-Up Photographer of the Year Awards
Now in its seventh year, the competition honors macro, micro and close-up images snapped around the world
Have you ever wondered what a tadpoleâ€™s first home looks like, or the fine details of a mushroomâ€™s underside? Welcome to the Close-up Photographer of the Year awards, where artists get up close and personal with natural and human-made wonders around the world.
This year marked the seventh annual competition, and it drew more than 12,000 entries from 63 countries. A 22-person panel of photographers, naturalists and editors spent some 20 hours selecting winners and runners-up in 11 different categories. They also chose a grand award recipient, who takes home a cash prize of about $3,400.
â€œThis was the toughest competition yet,â€ says Tracy Calder, the competitionâ€™s co-founder, in a statement. â€œThe winning image embodies everything close-up photography can achieveâ€”it shows us a perspective weâ€™ve never seen before and reveals hidden beauty in a familiar subject. The judges were captivated.â€
To see more finalists for each category, check out the awardsâ€™ website. For anyone feeling inspired, the eighth CUPOTY awards will open for submissions in May.
Here is the grand award-winning image, which also won the underwater category, and the top photos in the ten other categories.
Grand Award and Underwater: Fractal Forest by Ross Gudgeon
This coral usually looks like a common white veggie: the humble cauliflower. The aptly named cauliflower soft coral is made of â€œcountless small, rounded, bump-like polyps that give it a puffy texture,â€ says Ross Gudgeon in a statement. But the photographer makes this coral in Lembeh Strait, Indonesia, look more like a forest of hulking pink trees.
To capture the image, Gudgeon threaded a small underwater lens called a Nauticam Extended Macro Wide Lens through the branches of the coral, â€œcreating an image looking from the inside out,â€ he says.
The species, native to waters around Australia, is endangered, and its population declined by more than 90 percent from 2011 to 2021, according to the Australian government.
Animals: Amphibian Galaxy by Filippo Carugati
Photographer Filippo Carugati spent six months with Malagasy frogs in Madagascarâ€™s Maromizaha rainforest gathering data for his doctoral thesis. During that time, he saw many of the amphibiansâ€™ sticky â€œegg clutchesâ€ with countless tadpolesâ€”and they showed a striking similarity to outer space.
Malagasy frogs mate en masse from November to May, when the climate in their Southern Hemisphere habitat is warmer and wetter than in the rest of the year. When Carugati wandered around at night during the breeding season, he was captivated by egg clutches attached to leaves, branches and tree trunks. The eggs are held together by a gelatinous substance, which provides the emerging tadpoles with their first home.
â€œUsing an external remote-controlled flash, I lit the subject from behind, enhancing the shapes of the converging tadpoles and the colorful mixture within the gelatine, which suggested a cosmic appearance,â€ Carugati says in a statement.
Insects: Blue Army by Imre PotyÃ³
Imre PotyÃ³ photographed endangered Danube mayflies in Hungary in the summer of 2024. The insects disappeared from the Danube River for decades, when its waters were extremely polluted, but they recently made a comeback.
Attracted to city lights, the creatures swarmed a festival in Szentendre. â€œDense clouds of mayflies engulfed the restaurants, vendors, wine bars and concerts, becoming an unmissable and alarming spectacle,â€ PotyÃ³ says in a statement. â€œThe mayflies circled around the lights for a long time, unable to break free, and sadly perished on the asphalt.â€
Such situations can be ecologically destructive for the species, as billions of mayflies and their eggs can dry out and die.
Butterflies & Dragonflies: Butterfly Flash by PÃ¥l Hermansen
Photographer PÃ¥l Hermansen captures a Camberwell beauty butterfly, also known as a mourning cloak, standing its ground. While feeding on a birch treeâ€™s sap in Follo, Norway, butterflies of another species and wasps descended in search of the same sappy snack. Instead of flying off, the Camberwell beauty flashed its wings several times to warn the interlopers to stay away.
â€œThe other insects kept their distance, allowing it to spend sufficient time feeding undisturbed,â€ Hermansen says in a statement.
Camberwell Beauty butterflies live and migrate individually rather than in swarms. The species is often found in chilly, mountainous areas in Europe and North America.
Arachnids: Dinner by Artur Tomaszek
Rather than capturing prey with silken webs, lynx spiders hunt prey by sight. During a sudden rainstorm in Hong Kong, thousands of termites emerged to swarm and mate, and this lynx spider had a field day. Photographer Artur Tomaszek snapped an image of it victoriously holding a meal.
â€œThe main difficulty in capturing the picture was the thousands of termites flying in my face, attracted by the cameraâ€™s flash,â€ he says. â€œIn the end, the spider managed to catch two or three termites at once, creating this striking scene.â€
Invertebrate Portrait: Good Boy by Laurent Hesemans
Laurent Hesemans came face-to-face with this silkworm moth in Tinamaste, Costa Rica, capturing a stunning portrait of an insect that the photographer describes as â€œincredibly photogenic.â€
â€œThe large eyes and antenna positions of these moths, especially the males, always lend their portraits a somewhat melancholy feeling,â€ Hesemans says in a statement. â€œThey are a lesson in beautiful subtlety and a reminder to always give even the simplest arthropods and small creatures a second, closer look.â€
Plants: Rebirth from Destruction by Minghui Yuan
Photographer Mingui Yuan was drawn to the combination of death and new life in this contrasting scene. Found in the Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden in China, the image shows decaying lotus leaves set against dark waters. Among the leaves sit bright green floating ferns, which prefer warm, tropical climates and clean waters.
â€œFinding it here amongst these skeletal leaves felt like the rebirth of hope and a symbol of the continuation of life,â€ Yuan says in a statement.
Fungi & Slime Moulds: Mushroom in the â€œNudeâ€ Style by Valeria Zvereva
This image, which photographer Valeria Zvereva describes in a statement as looking somewhat nude, depicts the underside of a lamellar mushroom in Russiaâ€™s Moscow area.
This close-up of the fungus focuses on its lamellae, or gills, which are attached to the bottom of some mushroomsâ€™ caps. The fungi developed these structures to increase their surface area, allowing for more space to produce spores. The tiny organisms get released into the air and grow into new mushrooms wherever they land.
Intimate Landscape: Dreamy State by Sho Hoshino
Photographer Sho Hosino contrasts lightness and darkness in this image of a frost-covered tree in front of a pale pink morning sky in Japanâ€™s Nagano prefecture, a landlocked region known for its mountainous landscape.
â€œThe composition relies on soft, pale tones anchored by the dark, intricate shape of the tree trunk and its distorted form,â€ Hoshino says in a statement. â€œAlthough the scene depicts the freezing cold of winter, the warm color tones give it a gentle sense of warmth rather than loneliness.â€
Studio Art: COPPER WORKS No. 25 by Paul Kenny
Much of artist Paul Kennyâ€™s portfolio contains imagery of natural landscapes. But a recent move to a major city â€œconjured up memories of my upbringing in the post-Industrial Revolution Lowry-esque landscape of inner-city Salfordâ€ in England, he says in a statement. â€œOver three years, a new body of work has emerged.â€
Household items have been capturing his imagination lately. This image depicts a copper plate that was distressed and oxidized by common chemicals found in most residences.
â€œThe fragments of flotsam and jetsam that formed the source of my medium have been replaced with the chemical fragments of common household materialsâ€”bleach, cleaners, gardening products, bathroom products,â€ Kenny says.
Young Close-up Photographer of the Year: Guardians of the Hive by Rithved Girish
Fourteen-year-old Rithved Girish loves finding beauty in the little things in life. â€œFascinated by the tiny wonders of nature, I make it a point to explore and learn more about the natural world whenever I visit India,â€ the photographer says in a statement.
During a trip to the village of Mezhathur in Kerala, India, Girish photographed this stingless bee nest, which is made of wax, resin and mud, and has a tube-shaped entrance. Guard bees stand alert at the entrance to protect their home from harm.
â€œThis image serves as a reminder of the vital role these tiny creatures play in maintaining ecological balance,â€ Girish says.

Ron Teasley, Pioneering Baseball Player and One of Two Surviving Negro League Veterans, Dies at 99
The former Brooklyn Dodger and New York Cuban leaves a lasting legacy of coaching and service in his hometown of Detroit
Ron Teasley, one of the last surviving veterans of the Negro Leagues and the eighth player to break Major League Baseballâ€™s racial barrier, died this week at the age of 99.
At his time of passing, the man they called â€œSchoolboyâ€ was the third-oldest living major leaguer, and one of just two surviving players to have suited up in a Negro Leagues game. Bill Greason, 101, is now believed to be the historic leagueâ€™s last living member.
â€œEvery time we lose one of these legendary athletes who called the Negro Leagues home, it takes a piece of us with them,â€ Bob Kendrick, president of the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum, tells KCTVâ€™s Betsy Webster.
Born in Detroit in 1927, Teasley attended Northwestern High School before enrolling at Wayne State University, where he lettered multiple times in both basketball and baseball. A first baseman and right fielder, Teasley wasted no time showcasing his five-tool talent. He hit .500 over 42 at-bats in his 1945 rookie seasonâ€”becoming the first player in university history to eclipse a .400 batting average. He also scored 12 runs and boasted a near-perfect .981 fielding percentage.
The next season was remarkable for entirely different reasons. Rather than return to the diamond, Teasley enlisted in the U.S. Navy and toured Saipan and the Western Pacific Islands during World War II. When his service ended, he played one more standout year at Wayne, leading the team with a .325 batting average in 40 at-bats. His performance garnered national attention.
The Brooklyn Dodgers reached out to Teasley ahead of the 1948 season and invited him to a spring training tryout in Vero Beach, Florida, where he impressed. On May 2â€”roughly 13 months after Jackie Robinson debuted for the Dodgers, breaking the MLBâ€™s color barrierâ€”Teasley became the eighth black ballplayer to sign a Major League contract.
â€œHe was actually signed by Branch Rickey, who was the same person who signed Jackie Robinson,â€ Ronald A. Teasley, his son, tells NPRâ€™s Debbie Elliott. â€œSo thatâ€™s kind of historic right there.â€Did you know? The oldest professional ballpark still being used in America is in Birmingham, Alabama.
- Rickwood Field was home to the Birmingham Black Barons, a Negro Leagues team from about 1920 to 1960.
The Dodgers assigned Teasley to the Olean Oilers, their minor league affiliate, whereâ€”along with fellow Detroiter Sammy Geeâ€”he became one of the first two black players in the Pennsylvania-Ontario-New York League. Despite batting a respectable .267 and leading the PONY league with three home runs and 23 hits in 23 games, he was released later that summer.
â€œYou had to be Hank Aaron or Willie Mays to make it at that time, and they knew we werenâ€™t Hank Aaron or Willie Mays when they signed us,â€ Teasley told the Detroit Free Pressâ€™s Scott Talley in 2024. â€œI wish I could say that everything was peaches and cream, but that was the saddest part and it was devastating at the time.â€
The Oilersâ€™ loss was the New York Cubansâ€™ gain. The 21-year-old Teasley finished the 1948 campaign with the historic Negro Leagues ball club, picking up two hits and two RBIs in two gamesâ€”though he may have played more, as many of the leagueâ€™s formal records and statistics have been lost.
Regardless of his playing time, his impact and legacy remain immeasurable.
â€œYou can't talk about baseball in the â€˜40s and â€˜50s in the African American community and Ron Teasley not be at the center of that conversation,â€ Layton Revel, a Negro League historian, tells NPR.
On the Cubans, Teasley wasnâ€™t the only standout player. He shared the dugout that year with a 24-year-old Minnie MiÃ±oso, who later signed with the Cleveland Indians to become Major League Baseballâ€™s first Afro-Latino player. MiÃ±osoâ€™s 17-season MLB career (15 with the Chicago White Sox) included nine All-Star Game selections and three Gold Glove Awards. In 2022, he was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
Teasley went on to play the next three seasons in Canadaâ€™s integrated Manitoba-Dakota League, where he was an All-Star selection himself, before returning to Wayne State and reinforcing his â€œSchoolboyâ€ nickname, which was given when he was a high school standout. In 1955, he graduated with a bachelorâ€™s in physical education; he would earn a masterâ€™s of administration in 1963. These degrees propelled him into a career of coaching and leadership in the very place his own athletic journey began: Northwestern High School in Detroit.
For more than two decades, beginning in 1968, Teasley coached varsity baseball at Northwestern. At least nine players reached the big leagues under his tutelage, and he was inducted into the Michigan High School Coaches Association Hall of Fame.
â€œWhen I joined the Negro Leagues, we would travel from city to city and the fans just welcomed usâ€”especially the African American fans,â€ Teasley told MLBPlayers.comâ€™s Jerry Crasnick a few years ago. â€œThey were so happy to see us. We played an outstanding brand of baseball, and they were so appreciative. I often think about thatâ€”how we would just encourage people to hang in there and work hard, and eventually things would change for the better.â€
